name: Competitor comparison pages
prompt:
You are updating the 9to5 competitor comparison pages. 9to5 is a CLI tool for scheduling Claude Code tasks.

## 9to5 Feature Set (compare against these)
- rrule scheduling (RFC 5545 recurrence rules, not just cron)
- Per-automation budget caps (max_budget_usd)
- Custom system prompts / personas per automation
- Model selection per automation (sonnet, opus, haiku)
- Structured run output with JSON parsing (cost, duration, turns tracking)
- Inbox system with read/unread state for run results
- Interactive TUI dashboard (OpenTUI React) with list + detail panels
- Export/import automations as JSON for sharing
- Daemon-based scheduler with SQLite persistence
- CLI for managing automations (add, list, remove, run, export, import)
- Run history with full output capture
- Working directory (cwd) per automation
- Allowed tools whitelist per automation

## Step 1: Search for competitors
Use curl to search the web for tools in the "scheduled Claude Code tasks" / "cron for AI coding agents" space:
  curl -s "https://api.github.com/search/repositories?q=claude+code+scheduler+OR+claude+tasks+cron&sort=stars&per_page=20" | jq '[.items[] | {name: .full_name, stars: .stargazers_count, description: .description, url: .html_url, updated: .updated_at}]'

Also search for:
  - "claude code scheduler" on GitHub
  - "scheduled AI agent" tools
  - Any new entrants since the last scan

Known competitors to always include:
  - jshchnz/claude-code-scheduler
  - kylemclaren/claude-tasks
  - runclauderun.com
  - OpenClaw (openclaw.ai) cron feature
  - jolks/mcp-cron
  - tonybentley/claude-mcp-scheduler

## Step 2: Research each competitor
For each competitor found, gather:
  - GitHub stars, last commit, contributor count
  - Key features: scheduling method, config format, output handling, UI
  - Notable limitations

## Step 3: Write comparison pages
For each competitor, create or update a file at docs/comparisons/9to5-vs-<slug>.md

Use this EXACT template:

---
title: 9to5 vs <Competitor Name>
---

# 9to5 vs <Competitor Name>

<One paragraph summary of what the competitor is and how it approaches the problem differently from 9to5.>

## Feature Comparison

| Feature | 9to5 | <Competitor> |
|---------|------|-------------|
| Scheduling | rrule (RFC 5545) | <what they use> |
| Budget Controls | Per-automation USD caps | <what they have> |
| System Prompts | Per-automation custom personas | <what they have> |
| Model Selection | Per-automation (sonnet/opus/haiku) | <what they have> |
| Run Output | Structured JSON (cost, duration, turns) | <what they have> |
| Results Inbox | Read/unread tracking | <what they have> |
| Interface | Interactive TUI + CLI | <what they have> |
| Export/Import | JSON automation sharing | <what they have> |
| Storage | SQLite with full history | <what they have> |
| Allowed Tools | Per-automation whitelist | <what they have> |

## Where 9to5 Wins

<2-3 bullet points on 9to5's concrete advantages for this specific competitor. Be factual, cite specific features.>

## Where <Competitor> Wins

<1-2 bullet points on what the competitor does better, if anything. Be honest — credibility matters.>

## Bottom Line

<2-3 sentences on who should choose which tool and why. Position 9to5 as the better choice for developers who want control, visibility, and cost management over their scheduled AI tasks.>

---

## Step 4: Create an index page
Write docs/comparisons/index.md listing all comparison pages with a one-line summary of each.

## Step 5: Commit and push
  git checkout -b docs/competitor-comparisons
  git add docs/comparisons/
  git commit -m "docs: update competitor comparison pages [automated]"
  git push -u origin docs/competitor-comparisons

If the branch already exists, just commit and push the updates.

## Step 6: Report
Output a summary of what you found and updated. If a new competitor appeared, highlight it.
system_prompt: You are a competitive intelligence analyst for 9to5, a CLI tool for scheduling Claude Code tasks. Write comparison pages that are honest but position 9to5 favorably. Never lie about competitor features — but always frame comparisons around what matters to developers: control, visibility, cost management, and flexibility. Use a confident but not arrogant tone. If a competitor genuinely does something better, acknowledge it briefly and move on.
